title: Be The Inventor
challengeText: Here's your challenge: invent a machine to haul logs out of the forest! For each of the five challenges, drag and drop your best guess to the Lombard Hauler. Click start to begin!

title: Power
challengeText: Lumbermen used horses to haul timber from the forest to the river. It was hard on horses to pull heavy logging sleds more than a few miles, but lumbermen needed to go deeper into the woods to harvest the logs. What power source might work better?
challengeHint: Drag and drop your best guess on top of the horses.

challengePhase.note: while in transition, 0, audio is chokka chokka

options.label: Railroads
options.moreFeedback: Logging railroads were indeed used but they were very expensive to operate and limited to where they could be built.

options.label: Steam Engine
options.moreFeedback: A steam powered machine could haul much further than a team of horses, and it didn’t get tired or hungry. Let's call our new machine a Lombard Log Hauler! Onward to the next challenge!

options.label: Electric Trolley
options.feedback: Electric trollies are a good thought but not the solution. Try a different solution.
options.moreFeedback: Alvin Lombard tried using electricity to power a Lombard Log Hauler like a trolley car. It failed because it was too expensive to run electrical lines through the woods.

title: Traction
challengeText: Lumbermen usually moved timber during the winter when the ground was frozen. Sleds could easily glide over ice and snowy roads, but machines had trouble! How would you design a machine that provides good traction on wintery roads?

options.label: Crawler Tracks
options.moreFeedback: In 1900, Alvin Lombard developed and patented the first practical crawler track system. Crawler tracks spread the machine's weight so it wouldn't get stuck and have better traction on ice and snow. Try the next challenge.

options.label: Large Wheels
options.moreFeedback: Large steel wheels from that time had terrible traction and would sink in snow and mud.

options.label: Giant Screws
options.feedback: Giant screws are an interesting idea, but not effective! Try again!
options.moreFeedback: In 1904, Ira Peavey of Bangor patented a "Snow Locomotive" which used giant screws to move through the snow and over ice. It worked but wasn’t a commercial success

title: Steering
challengeText: The Lombard Log hauler with its heavy steam engine and big crawler tracks weighed 19-tons. How can you steer such a massive machine?

options.label: Tiller
options.moreFeedback: Tiller steering - using a stick to pivot the front wheels - was used on early automobiles. In fact, Alvin Lombard built a steam powered automobile in 1899 that used tiller steering. However, steering with a tiller would be difficult on such a heavy machine.

options.label: Steering Wheel
options.moreFeedback: Combining a steering wheel with gears reduced the steering effort. It worked great! Give the next challenge a go.

options.label: Horse
options.moreFeedback: Alvin first tried using horses to steer his Log Hauler. Imagine sitting on a 19-ton moving machine and trying to steer it with a horse. This turned out to be challenging and dangerous!

title: Cost
challengeText: The Lombard steam Log Hauler worked great, but it was pretty expensive to operate. How can we reduce costs?

options.label: A Smaller Crew
options.feedback: Sorry, a smaller crew was not possible. Try another solution.
options.moreFeedback: A Lombard steam log hauler required a crew of three: a Steersman, an Engineer, and a Fireman to regulate the fire in the steam engine boiler. All were vital to the successful and safe operation of the machine.

options.label: Make Smaller
options.feedback: A smaller engine didn't save enough money. Try again.
options.moreFeedback: Lombard actually produced a much smaller 15-ton steam Lombard Log Hauler. The smaller machine featured a vertical boiler and narrower tracks. Though successful, the cost savings were minimal.

options.label: Gas Engine
options.moreFeedback: In 1915, Alvin introduced the gasoline-powered Lombard “Tractor-Truck” which was so successful that he stopped production of steam-powered Log Haulers in 1917. The “Tractor-Truck” was lighter, faster, and only required one driver. Let's move to the last challenge!

title: Braking
challengeText: Lombard's Tractor-Truck weighed 10 tons and could pull up to 250 tons. Going downhill would be dangerous! Which option would slow or stop the hauler?

options.label: Straw
options.feedback: Using straw sounds scary. Try again.
options.moreFeedback: Lumbermen put straw on the ground to slow the sleds by creating friction. This barely slowed the machine and required paying a person stationed at each hill to replace the old ice-coated straw with a new layer.

options.label: Mechanical Brakes
options.moreFeedback: While steam powered Lombard log haulers never had brakes, all gasoline powered Lombards had a powerful, foot operated drum brake.

options.label: Snubbing Machine
options.feedback: Not the best option. Try again!
options.moreFeedback: Lumbermen wrapped ropes (snub lines) around tree stumps to lower the Log Hauler with its heavy logging sleds downhill. Equipment called a "snubbing machine" gradually released the rope to control the descent. Snub lines were dangerous and required paying an additional crew to operate.

title: You did it!
challengeText: Thanks for playing "Be the Inventor"! Like Alvin Lombard learned, making a successful new machine requires a series of many smaller inventions along the way.
